arXiv:2410.04193v1 [cs.LG] 05 Oct 2024

Parametric Taylor series based latent dynamics identification neural networks

Xinlei Lin Dunhui Xiao xiaodunhui@tongji.edu.cn School of Mathematical Sciences, Key Laboratory of Intelligent Computing and Applications(Ministry of Education), Tongji University, Shanghai 200092, CHINA
Abstract

Numerical solving parameterised partial differential equations (P-PDEs) is highly practical yet computationally expensive, driving the development of reduced-order models (ROMs). Recently, methods that combine latent space identification techniques with deep learning algorithms (e.g., autoencoders) have shown great potential in describing the dynamical system in the lower dimensional latent space, for example, LaSDI, gLaSDI and GPLaSDI.

In this paper, a new parametric latent identification of nonlinear dynamics neural networks, P-TLDINets, is introduced, which relies on a novel neural network structure based on Taylor series expansion and ResNets to learn the ODEs that govern the reduced space dynamics. During the training process, Taylor series-based Latent Dynamic Neural Networks (TLDNets) and identified equations are trained simultaneously to generate a smoother latent space. In order to facilitate the parameterised study, a k𝑘kitalic_k-nearest neighbours (KNN) method based on an inverse distance weighting (IDW) interpolation scheme is introduced to predict the identified ODE coefficients using local information. Compared to other latent dynamics identification methods based on autoencoders, P-TLDINets remain the interpretability of the model. Additionally, it circumvents the building of explicit autoencoders, avoids dependency on specific grids, and features a more lightweight structure, which is easy to train with high generalisation capability and accuracy. Also, it is capable of using different scales of meshes. P-TLDINets improve training speeds nearly hundred times compared to GPLaSDI and gLaSDI, maintaining an L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error below 2%percent22\%2 % compared to high-fidelity models.

keywords:
reduced-order model, latent-space identification, sparse regression, Taylor series expansion, deep learning, equation discovery, ResNet

1 Introduction

In the fields of engineering and physics, the behaviours of many complex systems are governed by partial differential equations (PDEs)[1, 2, 3]. To describe and understand these systems through PDEs, physical simulations and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) provide essential guidance for advanced design and practical industry applications[4, 5]. During the past few decades, numerical methods such as the finite element method (FEM)[6] and the finite volume method (FVM)[7] have been continuously advancing, while significant progress has been made in computer hardware and GPUs simultaneously. However, as the demand for superior accuracy in discrete solutions increases and grids become highly refined, the computational requirements of these traditional methods become exceedingly considerable. This is especially evident for problems involving multiple repeated simulations, such as parametric problems[8, 9], where the expansion of modelling iterations leads to dramatic resource consumption. Consequently, these issues may lead to limitations in effective application in practice.

To overcome these limitations, reduced-order modelling (ROM) emerges as a promising approach that conquers the computational cost impediments in many areas, such as turbulent flows[10, 11, 12], aerodynamics[13] digital twins[14], biomedical sciences[15], finance[16], meteorology science[17], geosciences[18], aerospace[19] and plasma dynamics[20]. The primary objective of ROM is to reduce the dimensions of full-order models by projecting the system onto a lower-dimensional latent linear or non-linear subspace. Typically, ROM achieves remarkable speed enhancements compared to high-fidelity models, albeit with a negligible decrease in accuracy, rendering it incredibly attractive. The parameterised nonlinear reduced order methods (P-NIROM)[21] is a method designed for quick prediction and reliable simulation of parameterised partial differential equations (P-PDEs), e.g. the Navier-Stokes equations.

Popular linear reduced-order methods include proper orthogonal decomposition (POD)[22], Galerkin projection[23], dynamic mode decomposition (DMD)[24] and reduced basis method (RB)[25]. Autoencoders, a nonlinear projection technique in reduced-order models, demonstrate impressive capabilities in dimensionality reduction[12, 26]. They have already been widely applied in various fields such as aerodynamic wing design[27], fluid dynamics[28], Magneto hydrodynamics (MHD)[29], high-energy physics[30] and long-span bridge building[31]. The combination of autoencoders with neural network architectures, such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs)[32], recurrent neural networks (RNNs)[33], long short-term memory networks (LSTMs)[34], residual neural networks (ResNets)[35], transformers[36], DeepONets[37] etc., has shown high efficiency in reduced modelling and prediction tasks. In addition to autoencoders, there are other network structures that can achieve dimension reduction, such as generative adversarial networks (GANs)[38], t-distributed stochastic neighbour embedding (t-SNE)[39], transfer learning[40] and Latent Dynamics Networks[41]. In particular, Latent dynamic networks (LDNets)[41] provide a brand new perspective in ROM community, which automatically learns and discovers low-dimensional features of dynamic systems, i.e., latent state variables.

The discovery of governing equations in latent spaces is a particularly promising approach to address the challenges since the dynamics in the latent space can be identified as a set of ordinary differential equations (ODEs). These identified governing equations can be easily solved and mapped back to the high-dimensional flow field solution space. In other words, these ODEs are better for revealing the underlying physical or mathematical laws of model learning, leading to improved model interpretability and enhanced generalisation. The sparse identification of nonlinear dynamics (SINDy)[42], as a method of dynamics identification, through the use of a function library and sparse linear regression, has seen widespread applications and led to the development of several related parametric PDE algorithms[43, 44, 45, 46], such as PDE-FIND[47], RE-FIND[48], LaSDI[45], gLaSDI[44] and GPLaSDI[46]. By extracting coefficients from latent governing equations and combining them with interpolation or fitting methods, such as radial basis function (RBF) interpolation[49], Gaussian process regression (GPR)[46], or linear interpolation techniques, efficient and effective evaluation and prediction are easily achieved across the whole parameter space.

In this paper, inspired by the latent dynamics networks (LDNets) proposed by [41], a new Multiscale Parametric Taylor series-based Latent Dynamics Identification Neural Networks (P-TLDINets) are presented. The P-TLDINets are constructed via Taylor series expansions, ResNets, and k𝑘kitalic_k-nearest neighbours (KNN) algorithm combined with an inverse distance weighting (IDW) interpolation schema. Apart from identifying latent equations like LDNets, P-TLDINets can be applied to more complex parametric PDE problems, for example, problems in which the initial conditions vary with the parameters. The LDNets can only solve parametric problems where the initial conditions do not change with the parameters. In addition, the P-TLDINets model uses only a small amount of high-fidelity training data to achieve accurate, robust, and efficient data-driven reduced-order modelling for physical systems. Furthermore, the P-TLDINets is a multiscale model which is capable of running simulations with variable meshes. This allows P-TLDINets to predict high-dimensional approximation data at any query point 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x in the computational domain ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω, even if some of them may not be part of the training grids. This is another novelty for the newly presented P-TLDINets.

The subsequent part of the paper is organised as follows: Section 2 describes the related governing equations for parametric systems. The framework of P-TLDINets includes several parts, such as a family of networks called Taylor series-based Latent Dynamics Networks (TLDNets) in Section 3 and Identification of Dynamics (ID models) in latent space in Section 4. Section 5 shows the KNN method and the interpolating process. Section 6 is data preprocessing, including data sampling and normalisation of P-TLDINets. The whole framework of P-TLDINets is summarised in Section 7. The capabilities of P-TLDINets are demonstrated using two numerical examples: 2D-Burgers equations in 8.1 and lock exchange in 8.2. Furthermore, we test the effectiveness of the P-TLDINets model on multiscale problems to show its greater versatility. Through these examples, P-TLDINets demonstrate their distinct differences and superiority over autoencoder-based latent dynamics identification methods. Finally, we summarise the main innovations and applications prospects of the proposed model, providing a comprehensive overview of this research in Section 9.

In this work, the P-TLDINets includes two components: Taylor series-based Latent Dynamic Networks (TLDNets) and Identification of Dynamics models (ID models). They are introduced in Section 3 and Section 4 respectively.

3 Taylor series-based Latent Dynamic Neural Networks (TLDNets)

The Taylor series-based Latent Dynamic Networks (TLDNets) consist of three network structures, involving the dynamic network N⁢Nd⁢y⁢n𝑁subscript𝑁𝑑𝑦𝑛NN_{dyn}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_y italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the reconstruction network N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the initial mapping network N⁢Nz0𝑁subscript𝑁subscript𝑧0NN_{z_{0}}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, corresponding to the model parameters Wd⁢y⁢nsubscript𝑊𝑑𝑦𝑛W_{dyn}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_y italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Wr⁢e⁢csubscript𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑐W_{rec}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wz0subscript𝑊subscript𝑧0W_{z_{0}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively. They are constructed using fully connected neural networks (FCNNs) and residual neural networks (introduced in Section 3.3). These three networks are used to compute the time derivatives of the latent state variables, reconstruct the scalar data 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u, and generate the initial latent states respectively. The traditional latent dynamics networks (LDNets) consist of two neural networks for dynamics learning and reconstruction respectively, but cannot be used on parametric problems with initial values varying with parameters, which limits their capacity of generalisation. To solve this, a brand new FCNN structure N⁢Nz0𝑁subscript𝑁subscript𝑧0NN_{z_{0}}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, introduced in Section 3.2 in detail, is added to TLDNets so that they are able to be adapt to more situations. Besides, ResNets and Taylor series expansion theory are integrated into TLDNets to enhance the representation ability of P-TLDINets, enabling their application to more complex fluid cases.

In particular, in contrast to traditional dimension reduction methods, the structure of TLDNets ensures that its network parameters are significantly fewer compared to an autoencoder, leading to less training time and random access memory (RAM) utilisation rate. Furthermore, a P-TLDINets model supports flexible coordinate input, thus, it can be classified as a mesh-free method.

3.2 The initial mapping model

The original network family LDNets in[41] could only be applied to parameterised problems with the same initial condition. 3.3 Residual Learning neural Network (ResNet)

Pure FCNNs have shown a considerable degree of superiority in function approximation across various fields[51]. However, as the depth of networks increases with the problem complexity of the architecture, deep learning models are prone to suffer from gradient vanishing and overfitting, resulting in weakened performance. The deep residual learning neural network (ResNet) is an architecture proposed to address these challenges to a certain extent, improving the ability of networks to capture more dynamics in data.

Instead of purely FCNNs, we use ResNet in the N⁢Nd⁢y⁢n𝑁subscript𝑁𝑑𝑦𝑛NN_{dyn}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_y italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT networks. ResNet was initially based on convolutional neural network (CNN) technology in the field of computer vision and image classification[35]. Here, the residual learning concept is applied to FCNNs. The main difference between residual learning and classical FCNNs lies in the structure of their networks, as shown in Figure 1. A FCNN consists of multiple hidden layers, where adjacent neurons are directly connected by weight matrices and biases, and then nonlinearity is provided by activation functions. In contrast, for a ResNet, there exists a shortcut path, connecting the input and output layers directly, known as a ”skip connection.”

Assume that the input to a ResNet block is X𝑋Xitalic_X, and set the corresponding mapping as ℋℋ\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H. In Figure 1, the weight layers consist of several linear neurons, and the activation function is the rectified linear unit (ReLU) function. Denote the mapping formed only by stacked nonlinear layers as ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. Then, the output of a single ResNet block can be expressed as

ℋ⁢(X):=ℱ⁢(X)+X.assignℋ𝑋ℱ𝑋𝑋\mathcal{H}(X):=\mathcal{F}(X)+X.caligraphic_H ( italic_X ) := caligraphic_F ( italic_X ) + italic_X . (6)

4 Identification of dynamics (ID model) in the latent space

Afterwards, ID models are applied in 𝒛∈𝒮𝒛𝒮\bm{z}\in\mathcal{S}bold_italic_z ∈ caligraphic_S to discover intrinsic characteristics of latent dynamics. Finally, according to the input spatial coordinate information 𝒙∈Ω𝒙Ω\bm{x}\in\Omegabold_italic_x ∈ roman_Ω, the reconstruction network N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT maps to the original flow fields, receiving the predicted value 𝒖~~𝒖\tilde{\bm{u}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_u end_ARG. The vector 𝒛𝒛\bm{z}bold_italic_z is equivalent to a compressed representation of the high-dimensional physical data 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u, defined over both time and space. The temporally-dependent 𝒛𝒛\bm{z}bold_italic_z reflects the physical features of the original solution manifold so that it can be viewed as a dynamical system governed by a set of ODEs. Here, consider the reduced-order dynamic identification model as follows:

In this paper, first-order polynomial terms and constant terms are used as components of 𝚯𝚯\bm{\Theta}bold_Θ. For each 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\bm{\mu}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a specific system of ODEs to identify the latent dynamics. In fact, during the physical training and discovery of ID models, evaluating the error between 𝒛isubscript𝒛𝑖\bm{z}_{i}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the estimated value 𝒛~isubscript~𝒛𝑖\tilde{\bm{z}}_{i}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is inefficient. This is because the right side of Equation 9 approximates the time derivative of 𝒛isubscript𝒛𝑖\bm{z}_{i}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e. 𝒛˙isubscript˙𝒛𝑖\dot{\bm{z}}_{i}over˙ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), rather than 𝒛isubscript𝒛𝑖\bm{z}_{i}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT itself, which must be obtained by solving ODEs. Consequently, the loss function in the ID model must be adjusted to account for the computational error in time differentiation, which can be summarised as

L⁢o⁢s⁢s=‖d⁢𝒛d⁢t−𝚯⁢(𝒛)⋅𝚵‖22.𝐿𝑜𝑠𝑠subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑡⋅𝚯𝒛𝚵22Loss=||\frac{d\bm{z}}{dt}-\bm{\Theta}(\bm{z})\cdot\bm{\Xi}||^{2}_{2}.italic_L italic_o italic_s italic_s = | | divide start_ARG italic_d bold_italic_z end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG - bold_Θ ( bold_italic_z ) ⋅ bold_Ξ | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (12)

This idea was first utilised by Brunton et al in [43], in which the errors in the time derivatives of both the original space (i.e. d⁢𝒖d⁢t𝑑𝒖𝑑𝑡\frac{d\bm{u}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_italic_u end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG) and the latent space (i.e. d⁢𝒛d⁢t𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑡\frac{d\bm{z}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_italic_z end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG) are factored in the loss function. However, considering that incorporating terms related to d⁢𝒖d⁢t𝑑𝒖𝑑𝑡\frac{d\bm{u}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_italic_u end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG would significantly increase computational costs and the risk of overfitting, only the loss in d⁢𝒛d⁢t𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑡\frac{d\bm{z}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_italic_z end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG is included in the loss function here.

For the low-dimensional data related to all training parameters in 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a joint training approach is employed in TLDNets by the loss function, simultaneously minimising the sum of MSE as follows:

5 k𝑘kitalic_k-Nearest Neighbour interpolation with inverse distance weighting

Based on latent ID models discovered from the training parameter set 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the corresponding high-dimensional data {𝒖i}𝝁i∈𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖subscript𝝁𝑖subscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\{\bm{u}_{i}\}_{\bm{\mu}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{train}}{ bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , low-dimensional dynamics can be explored at any unseen or trained parameter point 𝝁𝝁\bm{\mu}bold_italic_μ throughout the parameter space 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. To improve the efficiency of parametric study, the k𝑘kitalic_k-nearest neighbours (KNN) convex interpolation method is used to fit the learned ID model coefficient set {𝚵i}𝝁i∈𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscriptsubscript𝚵𝑖subscript𝝁𝑖subscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\{\bm{\Xi}_{i}\}_{\bm{\mu}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{train}}{ bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As an interpolation method with broad application prospects [53], the KNN approach captures the ID model coefficient values of each 𝝁𝝁\bm{\mu}bold_italic_μ from local features rather than globally, and offers greater accuracy compared to linear interpolation. In contrast to radial basis functions (RBF) and Gaussian process regression (GPR) methods, which ask optimisation to acquire interpolation weights, KNN-based interpolation results in lower computational costs and higher efficiency.

In this paper, we combine the inverse distance weighting (IDW) function with the KNN method as an interpolation technique. This integration ensures the convexity of the fitting interpolation problem and enhances robustness. For any testing parameter vector 𝝁∗∈𝒟superscript𝝁𝒟\bm{\mu}^{*}\in\mathcal{D}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D, denote the set of k𝑘kitalic_k nearest sample parameter points to 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as 𝒟⁢(𝝁∗)𝒟superscript𝝁\mathcal{D}(\bm{\mu}^{*})caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). The interpolation process is performed for each ODE coefficient (denoted as target y𝑦yitalic_y in Algorithm 1 for simplicity) at each parameter point. The mathematical description is as follows:

𝚵∗=ℐ⁢(𝝁∗;{𝚵i}i∈𝒟⁢(𝝁∗))=∑𝝁i∈𝒟⁢(𝝁∗)φi⁢(𝝁∗)⁢𝚵i,superscript𝚵ℐsuperscript𝝁subscriptsubscript𝚵𝑖𝑖𝒟superscript𝝁subscriptsubscript𝝁𝑖𝒟superscript𝝁subscript𝜑𝑖superscript𝝁subscript𝚵𝑖\bm{\Xi}^{*}=\mathcal{I}(\bm{\mu}^{*};\{\bm{\Xi}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{D}(\bm{% \mu}^{*})})=\sum_{\bm{\mu}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}(\bm{\mu}^{*})}\varphi_{i}(\bm{\mu% }^{*})\bm{\Xi}_{i},bold_Ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_I ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; { bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

where 𝚵∗superscript𝚵\bm{\Xi}^{*}bold_Ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the ID model coefficient matrix for the test parameter point 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and φi⁢(𝝁∗)subscript𝜑𝑖superscript𝝁\varphi_{i}(\bm{\mu}^{*})italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) represents the interpolation weights for each trained 𝚵isubscript𝚵𝑖\bm{\Xi}_{i}bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In the KNN method, the distance is determined by the Euclidean distance between the parameter points. Specifically, the distance between parameter points 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\bm{\mu}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is defined as

Note that the interpolation is actually performed on a per-parameter-point basis and the ODEs coefficients are predicted sequentially rather than all at once, to ensure accuracy. If there exists a 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\bm{\mu}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that d⁢(𝝁i,𝝁∗)≈0𝑑subscript𝝁𝑖superscript𝝁0d(\bm{\mu}_{i},\bm{\mu}^{*})\approx 0italic_d ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≈ 0, then it is concluded that 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is contained in 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 𝚵isubscript𝚵𝑖\bm{\Xi}_{i}bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is directly assigned to 𝚵∗superscript𝚵\bm{\Xi}^{*}bold_Ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The choice of k𝑘kitalic_k also affects the final prediction results. Following a preliminary screening process, the value k𝑘kitalic_k is determined to be 5. 6 Data pre-processing

6.1 Data sampling

There are various methods for the selection of the training parameter set 𝒟trainsubscript𝒟train\mathcal{D}_{\text{train}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To ensure training efficiency, commonly applied methods include greedy sampling based on training results or physical information[44, 46], uniform sampling[45], and Smolyak sparse grid method[54, 55]. The goal of these sampling methods is typically to improve the final performance of algorithms with as few parameter points as possible, especially for those based on autoencoders. This is because, compared to TLDNets, these algorithms, while also having an excellent ability to capture underlying dynamics, require more network parameters and take up more GPU memory, resulting in longer computation times and the need for more computational resources.

In our work, the random sampling method is used to choose 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For convenience and to observe the performance of P-TLDINets across the entire parameter domain 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, we uniformly sample a set of discrete parameter points 𝒟h⊂𝒟superscript𝒟ℎ𝒟\mathcal{D}^{h}\subset\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_D, with the number of points far exceeding that of 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}_{train}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e. |𝒟h|>|𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n|)|\mathcal{D}^{h}|>|\mathcal{D}_{train}|)| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | > | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | )), to serve as the testing sample set.

6.2 Normalisation

To enhance the training efficiency of the networks, we preprocess the training data. Especially, there is a need to normalise the inputs and outputs of P-TLDINets. These data include the parameter vector 𝝁𝝁\bm{\mu}bold_italic_μ, the scalar field 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u, and the spatial grid coordinate variable 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x. Each element is scaled to fit within a specific closed interval, usually chosen as [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ]. Based on the data distribution, the normalisation for each variable is conducted independently. The mathematical process is defined as follows:

β¯=(β−βr⁢e⁢f)/βw,¯𝛽𝛽subscript𝛽𝑟𝑒𝑓subscript𝛽𝑤\overline{\beta}=(\beta-\beta_{ref})/\beta_{w},over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG = ( italic_β - italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (18)

where βr⁢e⁢fsubscript𝛽𝑟𝑒𝑓\beta_{ref}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a reference value and βwsubscript𝛽𝑤\beta_{w}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a reference variable range. Particularly, if a variable takes values in the closed interval [αm⁢i⁢n,αm⁢a⁢x]subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝛼𝑚𝑎𝑥[\alpha_{min},\alpha_{max}][ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], then

{βr⁢e⁢f=(αm⁢i⁢n+αm⁢a⁢x)/2βw=(αm⁢a⁢x−αm⁢i⁢n)/2.\left\{\begin{aligned} &\beta_{ref}=(\alpha_{min}+\alpha_{max})/2\\ &\beta_{w}=(\alpha_{max}-\alpha_{min})/2.\end{aligned}\right.{ start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2 . end_CELL end_ROW (19)

If αm⁢i⁢n=−αm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝛼𝑚𝑎𝑥\alpha_{min}=-\alpha_{max}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, indicating that the origin is centred in [αm⁢i⁢n,αm⁢a⁢x]subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝛼𝑚𝑎𝑥[\alpha_{min},\alpha_{max}][ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], a range hyper-parameter ℒr⁢a⁢n⁢g⁢esubscriptℒ𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒\mathcal{L}_{range}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_a italic_n italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be set to adjust the normalisation range as follows:

{βr⁢e⁢f=ℒr⁢a⁢n⁢g⁢e⁢(αm⁢i⁢n+αm⁢a⁢x)/2βw=ℒr⁢a⁢n⁢g⁢e⁢(αm⁢a⁢x−αm⁢i⁢n)/2.\left\{\begin{aligned} &\beta_{ref}=\mathcal{L}_{range}(\alpha_{min}+\alpha_{% max})/2\\ &\beta_{w}=\mathcal{L}_{range}(\alpha_{max}-\alpha_{min})/2.\end{aligned}\right.{ start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_a italic_n italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_a italic_n italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2 . end_CELL end_ROW (20)

where ⊙direct-product\odot⊙ denotes the Hadamard product, i.e. element-wise product. This normalisation ensures that the input variables are within a standardised range, thereby facilitating more efficient network training. If removing normalisation, the networks can generally still achieve the fitting effect. However, it often requires more epochs of training and computational time.

7 Framework of P-TLDINets

The individual components of P-TLDINets have been described above. After preprocessing data, P-TLDINets focus on obtaining a family of ODE coefficients that can be used for parametric learning by training both the TLDNets and the ID model simultaneously. That is achieved by the total loss function as:

L⁢o⁢s⁢sm⁢o⁢d⁢e⁢l=L⁢o⁢s⁢sr⁢e⁢c⁢(Wr⁢e⁢c,Wd⁢y⁢n)+ωz0⁢L⁢o⁢s⁢sz0⁢(Wz0)+ωI⁢D⁢L⁢o⁢s⁢sd⁢z/d⁢t⁢(𝚵)+ωc⁢o⁢e⁢f⁢‖𝚵‖22,𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠𝑚𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑙𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠𝑟𝑒𝑐subscript𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑐subscript𝑊𝑑𝑦𝑛subscript𝜔subscript𝑧0𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠subscript𝑧0subscript𝑊subscript𝑧0subscript𝜔𝐼𝐷𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠𝑑𝑧𝑑𝑡𝚵subscript𝜔𝑐𝑜𝑒𝑓superscriptsubscriptnorm𝚵22Loss_{model}=Loss_{rec}(W_{rec},W_{dyn})+\omega_{z_{0}}Loss_{z_{0}}(W_{z_{0}})% +\omega_{ID}Loss_{dz/dt}(\bm{\Xi})+\omega_{coef}||\bm{\Xi}||_{2}^{2},italic_L italic_o italic_s italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_o italic_d italic_e italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_L italic_o italic_s italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_y italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_o italic_s italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_o italic_s italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_z / italic_d italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Ξ ) + italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | bold_Ξ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (22)

This process requires a long training time and is an offline training. Then, the KNN interpolation method is used based on the spatial characteristics of the testing parameters, and a series of latent parametric governing equations for each training parameter 𝝁𝝁\bm{\mu}bold_italic_μ are solved to predict latent state variables 𝒛~~𝒛\tilde{\bm{z}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG. The high-dimensional approximate flow field 𝒖~~𝒖\tilde{\bm{u}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_u end_ARG can be quickly simulated using the N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT model. This part is an online process, and it only takes a short time to reach the desired results. In addition, trained P-TLDINets allow for direct predictions of 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u based on the inputs of N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are independent spatial coordinates 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the testing parameter point 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The whole process refers to Equation 21.

According to the error between the estimated vector 𝒖~~𝒖\tilde{\bm{u}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_u end_ARG and the true value 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u, the parametric prediction and spatial prediction effectiveness of the model can be assessed by L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reconstruction rate as:

7.1 Off-line model training

The details mentioned in the previous sections together form the P-TLDINets algorithm based on parametric learning. In practice, after randomly selecting a parameter points subset 𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n⊂𝒟subscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝒟\mathcal{D}_{train}\subset\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_D, a small amount of high-fidelity snapshot is generated by simulation techniques as training data. These data are then fed into the P-TLDINets model after going through preprocessing, especially the normalisation process in Section 6.2. A series of latent governing equations with the form of Equation 7 are identified to describe the intrinsic dynamics. The coefficient matrices {𝚵i}subscript𝚵𝑖\{\bm{\Xi}_{i}\}{ bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of Equation 7 for each 𝝁i∈𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝝁𝑖subscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\bm{\mu}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{train}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , treated as trainable variables within the networks, are derived and compiled into a set for subsequent online computations as a significant ingredient of the parametric prediction. The specific procedure can be referred to Algorithm 2 and the flow chart is in Figure 2.

7.2 Online stage with the reconstruction model and ID models

The trained P-TLDINets model is then employed in efficient predictions of estimated solutions for a given parameter. During the online stage, the prediction for unknown parameter points, or even for spatial grid coordinates that were not included or partly missed in the training data, is able to be accomplished with reduced time and costs. By combining 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\bm{\mu}^{*}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT information with the set of coefficients {𝚵i}𝝁i∈𝒟t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscriptsubscript𝚵𝑖subscript𝝁𝑖subscript𝒟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\{\bm{\Xi}_{i}\}_{\bm{\mu}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{train}}{ bold_Ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, high-dimensional estimates is obtained through KNN convex interpolation and the trained network N⁢Nr⁢e⁢c𝑁subscript𝑁𝑟𝑒𝑐NN_{rec}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and N⁢Nz0𝑁subscript𝑁subscript𝑧0NN_{z_{0}}italic_N italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The detailed process is shown in Algorithm 3

8 Numerical Results

This section demonstrates the application of P-TLDINets. We explore P-TLDINets on two nemerical examples, the 2D-Burgers equation and lock exchange. Within the selected parameter range, the latter example can standardise initial values through certain preprocessing, while the former one cannot. The Burgers equation uses a uniform grid, whereas the lock-exchange problem uses an unstructured triangular mesh, ensuring that both are capable of high-fidelity numerical solutions. We depict the prediction performance and training speed of P-TLDINets with unknown testing parameters.

In the results presentation of the first example, this method is compared with some dynamics identification methods based on autoencoders. Additionally, two parameter ranges are used to demonstrate the generalisation ability of this framework. To illustrate the capability of P-TLDINets to handle different coordinates or meshes, we also added a subsection to these two numerical cases, where different scales of meshes (multiscale meshes) are fed into the model.

The training of P-TLDINets and the compared methods are all performed on a NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090 (Ada Lovelace) with 24GB GDDR6X GPU.

8.1 Case 1: 2D-Burgers equation

We consider a 2D parametric Burgers equation with a viscous diffusion term, which involves a governing equation and an essential boundary condition. It can be summarised as

To identify dynamics in the latent space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, linear terms and constant comprise the library 𝚯⁢(⋅)𝚯⋅\bm{\Theta}(\cdot)bold_Θ ( ⋅ ) in Equation 7, leading to Nb=6subscript𝑁𝑏6N_{b}=6italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 6. The coefficient matrix 𝚵𝚵\bm{\Xi}bold_Ξ is contained in the network as trainable variables. Compared to the autoencoder, this is a sufficiently lightweight structure, with fewer model trainable parameters, leading to more rapid model training and less use of random access unit.

The P-TLDINets model is trained by the Adam optimiser for 6000 iterations, with Nt⁢o⁢l=500subscript𝑁𝑡𝑜𝑙500N_{tol}=500italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_o italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 500. To further refine the training, a learning rate scheduler (StepLR) is implemented with an initial learning rate α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05italic_α = 0.05, which decreased α𝛼\alphaitalic_α by a factor of 0.6 every 500 iterations. 25 samples are randomly selected to estimate the latent dynamics. The loss weights are set as ωD⁢I=0.05subscript𝜔𝐷𝐼0.05\omega_{DI}=0.05italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.05, ωc⁢o⁢e⁢f=0subscript𝜔𝑐𝑜𝑒𝑓0\omega_{coef}=0italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, ωz0=0.5subscript𝜔subscript𝑧00.5\omega_{z_{0}}=0.5italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5.

All three methods roughly restore the trends of the flow fields, and Figure 6(b) presents that their errors remain within a very narrow range. To further demonstrate the effects of P-TLDINets, a large parameter dataset 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is employed in Section 8.1.2.

For Burgers equation, a larger range of parameters implies more complex dynamics. The network structure and training information are the same as those in the previous section. A new testing parameter point set, 𝒟2hsubscriptsuperscript𝒟ℎ2\mathcal{D}^{h}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, also containing 225 sample parameters, is selected from 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Figure 9 presents the prediction results of GPLaSDI, gLaSDI and P-TLDINets for the testing parameter 𝝁=[1.0,1.29]𝝁1.01.29\bm{\mu}=[1.0,1.29]bold_italic_μ = [ 1.0 , 1.29 ] when Ns=5subscript𝑁𝑠5N_{s}=5italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5. In 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, notice the change in the upper and lower bounds of the colour bar in Figure 9 (b), which implies that methods based on autoencoders fail to accurately generate high-dimensional approximate solutions as t𝑡titalic_t evolves. In contrast, P-TLDINets continue to demonstrate reconstruction capabilities similar to that on the smaller datasets 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In order to delve deeper into the causes of this phenomenon, Figure 10 depicts the low-dimensional states of the other two methods. It reveals that, in the larger parameter space 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the states learned by autoencoders show more complex forms, which limit the identification ability of models, potentially causing divergence when solving the latent governing equations. Comparing Figure 5 with Figure 8, it is clear that the latent performances of P-TLDINets are always smoother than that learned by autoencoders, regardless of the dimensionality of latent space. This is due to the properties of TLDNets. Therefore, this method is more generalisable.

8.1.3 Trained on multi-scale grids

This section demonstrates another capability of P-TLDINets, which is learning on multi-scale problems. P-PDE problems with multiple scales are commonly found in physical simulations and engineering applications[56, 57].

In this example, three types of square grids with different scales are fed into the model. The grids are shown in Figure 11. For simplicity, these grids are uniform and divided into 50, 60 and 70 segments along x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT axis and x2subscript𝑥2x_{2}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT axis respectively, resulting in 2500, 3600, and 4900 mesh points in total. The training data {𝒖}𝒖\{\bm{u}\}{ bold_italic_u } are generated according to the random selection in 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The other conditions and network structure are the same as those in the previous training. The trained model is then applied to make predictions on the grid (c) in Figure 11, which has 4900 nodes, achieving a reconstruction accuracy of 98.73%. Figure 12 show the specific prediction results of P-TLDINets at 𝝁∗=[0.64,1.21]superscript𝝁0.641.21\bm{\mu}^{*}=[0.64,1.21]bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ 0.64 , 1.21 ].

8.2 Case 2: Lock exchange

Lock-exchange is a classic numerical experiment in fluid mechanics, designed to analyse the mixing and flow behaviours between fluids of varying densities. A 2D rectangular flat-bottomed tank is filled with source fluid on one side and ambient fluid on the other, separated by a vertical gate in the middle. The source fluid has lower temperature and higher density, while the ambient fluid is the opposite. After the gate is removed, the denser fluid collapses under the lighter one. The two fluids gradually mix under gravity until viscosity dominates. The density interface between the source fluid and the ambient fluid forms Kelvin–Helmholtz billows[58], due to instability.

Assuming the temperature on the right side is T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and on the left side is −T0subscript𝑇0-T_{0}- italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the involved equations include several formulas from fluid mechanics. The incompressible fluid model can be written as:

{ρ⁢(∂u∂t+(u⋅∇)⁢u)=−∇p+ν⁢∇2u+ρ⁢g∇⋅u=0∂𝑻∂t+u⋅∇𝑻=α⁢∇2𝑻(x1,x2,t)∈Ω×[0⁢s,8⁢s]\left\{\begin{aligned} \rho\left(\frac{\partial\textbf{u}}{\partial t}+(% \textbf{u}\cdot\nabla)\textbf{u}\right)&=-\nabla p+\nu\nabla^{2}\textbf{u}+% \rho\textbf{g}\\[2.84544pt] \nabla\cdot\textbf{u}&=0\\[2.84544pt] \frac{\partial\bm{T}}{\partial t}+\textbf{u}\cdot\nabla\bm{T}&=\alpha\nabla^{2% }\bm{T}\quad(x_{1},x_{2},t)\in\Omega\times[0\rm{s},8\rm{s}]\end{aligned}\right.{ start_ROW start_CELL italic_ρ ( divide start_ARG ∂ u end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t end_ARG + ( u ⋅ ∇ ) u ) end_CELL start_CELL = - ∇ italic_p + italic_ν ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT u + italic_ρ g end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∇ ⋅ u end_CELL start_CELL = 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG ∂ bold_italic_T end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t end_ARG + u ⋅ ∇ bold_italic_T end_CELL start_CELL = italic_α ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_T ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) ∈ roman_Ω × [ 0 roman_s , 8 roman_s ] end_CELL end_ROW (32)

where the first equation is Navier-Stokes equation, the second represents the incompressibility condition, and the third is the energy equation, also known as the heat conduction equation. u is the velocity vector and p𝑝pitalic_p is the pressure. ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ stands for the fluid density. 𝑻𝑻\bm{T}bold_italic_T is temperature, which is the scalar data observed and learned in this case. Ω=[0⁢m,0.1⁢m]×[0⁢m,0.8⁢m]Ω0m0.1m0m0.8m\Omega=[0\,\rm{m},0.1\,\rm{m}]\times[0\,\rm{m},0.8\,\rm{m}]roman_Ω = [ 0 roman_m , 0.1 roman_m ] × [ 0 roman_m , 0.8 roman_m ]. Here, thermal diffusion is not considered.

The initial condition for velocity u and temperature 𝑻𝑻\bm{T}bold_italic_T is summarised as follows:

{u⁢(x1,x2,0)=0𝑻⁢(x1,x2,0)={−T0,x1<0.4⁢mT0.x1≥0.4⁢m\left\{\begin{aligned} \textbf{u}(x_{1},x_{2},0)&=0\\ \bm{T}(x_{1},x_{2},0)&=\begin{cases}-T_{0},&\quad x_{1}<0.4\,\rm{m}\\ T_{0}.&\quad x_{1}\geq 0.4\,\rm{m}\end{cases}\end{aligned}\right.{ start_ROW start_CELL u ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 ) end_CELL start_CELL = 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_T ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 ) end_CELL start_CELL = { start_ROW start_CELL - italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.4 roman_m end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.4 roman_m end_CELL end_ROW end_CELL end_ROW (33)

The lock exchange adopts a no-slip boundary condition, meaning that the velocity remains zero at the bottom of the domain. The other relevant physical configurations are shown in Table 3.

The high-fidelity solutions are obtained using an unstructured mesh finite element model, Fluidity[59, 60]. The time interval is set to Δ⁢t=0.005⁢sΔ𝑡0.005s\Delta t=0.005\rm{s}roman_Δ italic_t = 0.005 roman_s. The grid is non-uniform and holds constant over time. Considering that the flow characteristics of the lock exchange may present more dynamic variability in the middle section, a grid refinement is employed between 0.2⁢m≤x≤0.6⁢m0.2mx0.6m0.2\rm{m}\leq x\leq 0.6\rm{m}0.2 roman_m ≤ roman_x ≤ 0.6 roman_m.

Figure 13 and Table 4 illustrate the dimensionality reduction performances across various low-dimensional spaces. It is clear that P-TLDINets still show greater smoothness, even under more intricate dynamical systems in this case. This feature enhances the effectiveness of subsequent equation identification and facilitates predictions with a 176.5×176.5\times176.5 × speed-up.

8.2.2 Trained on multi-scale grids

In the lock-exchange scenario, grids of different scales are also tested. These grids obey the sparsity characteristics described previously and are depicted in Figure 16. These three grids have 1894, 1491, and 1278 spatial points respectively. The high-dimensional data {𝒖}𝒖\{\bm{u}\}{ bold_italic_u } are generated by Fluidity on these three grids for network training as input. Finally, predictions are made on grid (c) in Figure 16. The prediction results achieves 97.00% recovery accuracy. Figure 17 presents the specific prediction results of P-TLDINets at 𝝁∗=[5.00,4.214×10−6]superscript𝝁5.004.214superscript106\bm{\mu}^{*}=[5.00,4.214\times 10^{-6}]bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ 5.00 , 4.214 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ].

9 Conclusion

This paper introduces Multiscale Parametric Taylor series-based Latent Dynamics Identification Networks (P-TLDINets), a novel dimensionality reduction neural network for the purpose of robust, accurate, effective and resource-efficient data-driven computation. The proposed model integrates with Taylor series-based Latent Dynamic Networks Latent Dynamics Networks (TLDNets) and Identification of Dynamics (ID models), which are the core strengths in our work as well. Three sub-networks and coefficients of ID models are trained simultaneously and interactively, facilitating a simple and smoother discovery of latent dynamics. In order to enhance the exploration in parameter spaces, a state-of-the-art k𝑘kitalic_k nearest neighbour (KNN) method based on inverse distance weighting (IDW) is used to predict approximate scalar fields of unknown parameter samples incorporating with spatial information.

To demonstrate the utility of P-TLDINets, it has been applied to dynamical problems with nonlinear characteristics, including 2D Burgers’ equations and the lock-exchange case. Numerical results show that, compared to autoencoders based latent identification methods, P-TLDINets are equipped with a lighter structure and superior performances, tending to reflect better learning capabilities in more complex parameter spaces with less training time. In addition, it is able to deal with multiscale meshes. The L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT errors of the P-TLDINets remain consistently below 2%percent22\%2 %, achieving a significant computational speedup.

P-TLDINets provide a transformation from leading-edge modelling reductions (such as methods based on POD and autoencoders). In detail, instead of explicitly constructing an autoencoder based on high-dimensional discrete coordinates, P-TLDINets automatically generate a latent representation of the system’s states and implement a direct query for individual spatial coordinates. Additionally, it addresses the limitations of LDNets in handling problems with varying initial conditions, thereby broadening its generalisation performance. The ID model improves interpretability in low-dimensional spaces, and the concept of locally identifiable predictions makes P-TLDINets more competitive.

The presented parametric framework is generalisable, allowing for the integration of other sampling (such as greedy sampling) and other interpolation methods. P-TLDINets, as a multiscale model actually, not only accommodate input with varying grids during training procedure, but also enhance spatial flexibility in the online reconstruction process. This enables P-TLDINets to handle multiscale meshes relatively easily, paving the way for future applications in adaptive meshing and other aspects.
